docs.lead_paragraph: IN the debate over the affordability of health care, state-mandated insurance benefits are getting plenty of attention. The mandates require insurers who sell policies in a particular state to offer or provide certain coverage. But some states have passed laws that let insurers sell bare-bones policies that don't offer these benefits. And a bill is wending its way through Congress to permit so-called association health plans that let employers band together to buy health insurance and bypass these laws. Business groups argue that state-mandated benefits contribute significantly to rising health costs and make it difficult for many employers, especially small businesses that lack bargaining power, to buy insurance.

headline.main: Paying a Price for Pared-Down Health Plans

docs.abstract: Michelle Andrews column on minimum benefits health insurers must offer in some states and efforts to bypass such state mandates; notes pressure from some business groups to let employers form associations to buy less-expensive, less-comprehensive coverage; cites Congressional Budget Office study that found benefit mandate exemptions would cut premiums by no more than 5 percent and increase rate at which small companies offer health insurance by just 3 percent; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BESIDES offering kayak tours from their headquarters in the old 1920's bathhouse in Kingsland Point Park in Sleepy Hollow, employees of Hudson River Recreation prune trees, paint over graffiti and clear patches of poison ivy. The business makes no profit. ''I thought it was a good thing to do,'' said Michael Doorley, a financial services executive and outdoor enthusiast who subsidizes the establishment from his own pocket. ''The only way to make money would be to bring on more staff, but it's very risky. If I had a full staff on hand these past few months, I'd have been out of business already. Some guys buy BMW's, I do this.''
docs.abstract: Article on some of 18 concessions in parks around Westchester County, NY; Hudson River Recreation, based in Kingsland Point Park in Sleepy Hollow, offers kayak tours, prunes trees, paints over graffiti and clears patches of poison ivy; River Ridge Equestrian Center in Twin Lakes Park teaches horseback riding; county also farms out 13 food outlets at county parks, pools and golf courses to nine different companies; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SOMEWHERE between climbing six flights of stairs and dancing a gavotte on the rug, Salvador Gonzalo Diaz Baldizon, who says he is 102, lamented the confession he made to the priest on his 100th birthday about all the women he'd been with. Born in the mountains of Guatemala, Mr. Diaz, who is a Maya Indian and looks as if he walked off the pages of the Old Testament, told the priest of the 33 children he had with nine different women, only one of whom he married. ''Your penance is to not have any more women,'' Mr. Diaz recalled the priest saying. ''Love and respect God. No more women.'' Asked if he agreed with the priest's words, Mr. Diaz waved at the air in disagreement. ''No,'' he said. ''But I promised not to have more. And now I'm lonely.''
docs.abstract: Marek Fuchs County Lines column on Salvador Gonzalo Diaz Baldizon of White Plains, NY, Maya Indian born in Guatemala who says he is 102; Diaz, who lives alone and runs errands every day at Westchester Mediation Center of CLUSTER Inc, comments on secrets of his longevity; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Kendal Corporation, a 30-year-old, nonprofit Quaker organization that builds and operates retirement communities, is building a $150 million, 600,000-square-foot continuing-care development for about 350 residents on the grounds of Phelps Memorial Hospital in Sleepy Hollow. Under the agreement, the hospital will lease 20 of the 64 acres it owns overlooking the Hudson River to Kendal and offer its services to residents. The project is only the second in New York for the group, which is based in Kennett Square, Pa. and provides housing, services and long-term care based on the principles of the Religious Society of Friends. Among those principles are that no pharmaceutical or physical restraints are used when caring for the frail and the elderly.

headline.main: In the Region/Westchester; $150 Million Continuing-Care Unit in Sleepy Hollow
